item.title: My Solution to the Meaning of Life
item.description: I promised last week to explain the epiphany that led me to make peace with my fear of death. It was based on the realization that I am connected to all of my ancestors. This is going to get deep, so bear with me. So here's the explanation. Zooming out from my personal experience of life, I'm just one iteration of a genetic lineage. In fact, from a particular perspective, the real agent of this experience of existence is not me, Khaled, a human individual alive here and now, but rather the series of individual organisms connected by a genetic history.

item.title: How I Turn Fear into Inspiration
item.description:
I've been struggling with my mortality lately. Every few years, I go through periods of my life when I'm hyperaware that I won't be around forever, that this is my only chance to live, and afterwards it will be Eternity of....

I know I'm not unique in this way. All humans know they are going to die, and that awareness has been a driving force in human behavior.

I don't know how other people respond to that reality. I experience a compression of time, and all of a sudden, the decades between now and my death seem utterly trivial, the end as urgent and imminent as the next five minutes. It's really unpleasant.

I do believe in more compassionate explanations of existence than the walking-bag-of-chemical-reactions-becomes-worm-food. The Buddhist and Taoist concepts of universal oneness have a ring of truth to me. Of course, knowing that intellectually is very different from knowing it as a foundational principle of your worldview. Despite everything, I have to admit the dark, hopeless view often seems more real to me, even if it doesn't really make sense based on my beliefs.

This awareness of the imminence of death has been a defining feature of my life since I was very young. It has shaped my worldview and left a strong impression on my sense of values. For a long time, I simply accepted it as a terrible curse, but I eventually realized that I could choose what it meant to me.

So I chose to to interpret it in a way that empowers me and allows me to be happy.

item.title: The Imminence of Death
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_1754" align="alignright" width="300" caption="Kretyen on Flickr"][/caption]

Since I was a little kid, I’ve had a powerful sense of the imminence of my own death. Not that I expected to die in the near future, but I was always painfully aware that one day would be my last, and eventually, I would cease to experience anything ever again. I would get panic attacks mulling over the reality of my mortality. For a 9 year-old kid, that’s pretty heavy stuff. I still sometimes catch my mind wandering over to the other side, and as a result, my whole life I’ve carried with me an urgency to make the most of my time. I don’t know whether this is common or not, but I’m just acutely aware that one day, there will be no more me.
